section.p: You may have a need to add a network node for additional virtual machine capacity or another purpose and these steps will help you achieve this.

ol.li: Adding the new network node to monitoring

sectiondiv.p: You should have one or more baremetal servers that meet the minimum hardware requirements for a network node which are documented in the Hardware Support Matrix.

These steps will show you how to add the new network node to your servers.yml file and then run the playbooks that update your cloud configuration. You will run these playbooks from the lifecycle manager.

ol.li: Log in to your lifecycle manager.
Checkout the site branch of your local git so you can begin to make the necessary edits: cd ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data git checkout site

In the same directory, edit your servers.yml file to include the details about your new network node(s).
For example, if you already had a cluster of three network nodes and needed to add a fourth one you would add your details to the bottom of the file in this format: # network nodes - id: neut3 ip-addr: 10.13.111.137 role: NEUTRON-ROLE server-group: RACK2 mac-addr: "5c:b9:01:89:b6:18" nic-mapping: HP-DL360-6PORT ip-addr: 10.243.140.22 ilo-ip: 10.1.12.91 ilo-password: password ilo-user: admin
You can find detailed descriptions of these fields here. You will need to verify that the ip-addr value you choose for this node does not conflict with any other IP address in your cloud environment. You can confirm this by checking the ~/helion/my_cloud/info/address_info.yml file on your lifecycle manager.

In your control_plane.yml file you will need to check the values for member-count, min-count, and max-count, if you specified them, to ensure that they match up with your new total node count. So for example, if you had previously specified member-count: 3 and are adding a fourth network node, you will need to change that value to member-count: 4.
See Input Model - Control Plane for more details.
Commit the changes to git: git commit -a -m "Add node <name>"
Run the configuration processor: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Run the ready deployment playbook: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Add the new node into Cobbler: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-deploy.yml

Then you can image the node: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost bm-reimage.yml -e nodelist=<hostname> If you don't know the <hostname> already, you can get it by using sudo cobbler system list
Before proceeding, you may want to take a look at info/server_info.yml to see if the assignment of the node you have added is what you expect. It may not be, as nodes will not be numbered consecutively if any have previously been removed. This is to prevent loss of data; the config processor retains data about removed nodes and keeps their ID numbers from being reallocated. See the Persisted Server Allocations section in HPE Helion OpenStack 2.0 Input Model for information on how this works.
Run the following command: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts osconfig-run.yml --limit <hostname>

Run this command to complete the deployment of your new node, ensuring you use the --limit option to specify your new node: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-deploy.yml --limit <hostname>
Next run verb_hosts site.yml so that all other services become aware of the new node:ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts site.yml --tags "generate_hosts_file"
